Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolutionary strategies for adaptation in Wolbachia, a reproductive symbiont of arthropods.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study the process of evolution of species that live in close association and benefit each other, symbioses. Wolbachia is a bacterium, commonly found in close associations with insects, that co-opts the reproduction of an insect host to ensure its own transmission. The specific lifestyle of Wolbachia, and the ways in which it manipulates insects, provide a unique opportunity to (1) study the evolution of symbiosis, and (2) develop alternative methods for controlling insect populations including disease transmitting mosquitoes and common pests of homes and crops. However, the successful transfer of Wolbachia from one species to new target insect species has proven difficult, likely because Wolbachia is not adapted to the new species of insect since they have not coevolved. The research project will use a novel system to create variation in the genome of an insect species that is already part of a natural symbiosis with Wolbachia. Changes in both the insect and Wolbachia will then be tracked over time, as Wolbachia adapts to the newly created genetic variation present in its host. Beyond informing the development of novel insect control strategies, elucidating the adaptive process in Wolbachia may help us understand other bacteria-host interactions.

The research approach is to create genetic variation in a host insect by making a series of recombinant isofemale lines of the parasitic wasp, Trichogramma pretiosum, and subsequently to track the performance of Wolbachia in each of those lines. Compared to the original host, Wolbachia performs poorly in the recombinant hosts initially, but is able to adapt to the new insects in a short time span. Using this system, changes to both Wolbachia and Trichogramma pretiosum can be used to identify genes and molecular pathways that are important in the early stages of symbiont establishment. A genome re-sequencing approach will be used to identify mutations in the Wolbachia genome. Reciprocally, transcriptional activity of the wasps will be compared at early and late time points using RNA-Seq, so as to identify how the insect responds to the evolving symbiont. This system provides a platform with which to study changes to the genomes, physiology, and phenotypes of symbionts and hosts during co-evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wolbachia are a unique group of bacteria that infect insects and manipulate their reproductive mode and reproductive success. These bacteria have drastic effects on insect population growth and spread. As such, it is important to understand how these bacteria adapt to particular insect hosts, and what factors contribute their their ability to modify reproduction. Here, we use tiny parasitoid wasps of the genus Trichogramma, and their resident Wolbachia that convert the wasps to an asexual mode of reproduction to answer these questions. In this association, Wolbachia converts eggs that would normally develop as males into eggs that then develop into females. In collaboration with i5k, the initiative to sequence 5,000 arthropod genomes, we generated reference genomes for Trichogramma pretiosum, and its Wolbachia strain wTpre to enable genomic and molecular studies of this symbiotic associataion. We identified unique features of these genomes, and now have additional Trichogramma and Wolbachia genomes in the works that will support comparative analyses of these organisms.

We looked at environmental and genetic factors that mediate the strength of the Wolbachia-induced switch in reproduction. We found that how many eggs the wasps lay early on in their life plays a major role in the ability of Wolbachia to convert the offspring to female. We also looked at how Wolbachia performs in new wasp genotypes, and find that this particular Wolbachia strain is not as host-specific as was previously thought. Taken together these results help to explain the prevalence of Wolbachia in Trichogramma populations and the constraints that the symbiosis is subjected to. To better understand the physiology of the interaction, we looked at gene expression and epigenetic signatures of Wolbachia infection in these wasps newly infected with the symbiont. We identified candidate genes that may be responsible for the infectivity and changes in host reproduction that we see. These data are a valuable look into how these organisms interact with and adapt to each other. Beyond having a more thorough understanding of Wolbachia and symbiotic interactions, these results inform and may help improve biological control programs that use Trichogramma wasps to kill agricultural pests.

This study system is easy to manipulate in the lab, and a great opportunty to introduce students to the scientific process. We trained two undergraduate researchers in the lab to work on the long-term effects of Wolbachia infection in these wasps. Additionally, we have brought our science to our community through a variety of platforms including blogging, social media, outreach events, and the Annual Riverside Insect Fair.
